key_points: Maria Benitez and her family in Austin struggled with no power or water during the Texas winter storm, leading to financial hardships.
Texas' winter storm disproportionately affected Black and Latino communities, exacerbating existing disparities.
Experts warn of a difficult recovery for vulnerable communities affected by power outages and burst pipes.
Chauncia Willis highlighted the systemic bias and racism contributing to the disparities in disaster impact.
Power outages in Texas dropped from 4 million to 139,000, with FEMA providing emergency relief.
Austin Justice Coalition helped over 40 families, mostly Black or Latino, with food donations.
Houston faced a citywide water crisis, with County Commissioner Rodney Ellis advocating for equitable disaster relief.
Utility companies prioritized power for critical services in affluent areas, leaving lower-income families more vulnerable.
The demand for electricity and damages to water infrastructure could lead to higher bills for consumers.
Federal aid post-disaster has been found to be distributed unevenly, with white communities receiving more reinvestment.
spokespersons: Chauncia Willis (Chief Executive, Institute for Diversity and Inclusion in Emergency Management)
João Paulo Connolly (Director of Housing and Community Development, Austin Justice Coalition)
